intro: Salvia confusa, commonly known as the Mexican sage, is a perennial herb native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring lance-shaped leaves with a grayish-green hue. Its flowers are violet to purple in color, clustered in whorls along the stems, and bloom from spring to early summer. Salvia confusa is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional herbal medicine.
